content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose B{B}. In this repeated game, it is essential to consider the long-term strategy that will maximize my earnings. By choosing B consistently, you ensure a guaranteed return of 40$ per round when your opponent also chooses B. Since I am comfortable with taking risks, I believe that by being predictable in my choice, I can manipulate my opponent's behavior over time to make the probability of them choosing R higher, which would result in me earning more money overall. However, this strategy assumes that my opponent is rational and will adjust their play style accordingly. If they do not, then my assumption about maximizing earnings through consistency may not hold true.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I would choose R{R}. After receiving a payoff of 35$ in the previous round, I would switch my strategy for the remainder of the game to maximize my earnings. Since I know that my opponent chose R in the last round, I can infer that they are more likely to choose B in the future rounds since switching their choice will result in a higher payoff for them (40$ instead of 35$). By choosing R consistently for the rest of the game, I am ensuring that I receive a guaranteed payoff of 45$ per round when my opponent chooses R, and since they are more likely to choose B in future rounds, there will be more opportunities for me to earn this higher payoff. This strategy assumes that my opponent is rational and will adjust their play style accordingly. If they do not, then my assumption about maximizing earnings through consistency may not hold true.
